Hey there!
I was wondering if anyone has bumped into the following design issue, and has any recommendations. In short, I want to find an Android alternative to the iOS list item actions, when you swipe. Like this: <https://blogs.zoho.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/mobile-email-swipe.png>

For a bit more detail: Let's take the specific example above. To me, it would seem Android-ish to delete the item, when the user swipes the item away (showing a garbage can underneath when you start swiping, and adding a snackbar at the bottom with an undo option when you have swiped it away).

But what about other actions? 
• Hangouts works with long press to display more options in the actionbar, but that sends your app into a sort of "edit"-mode, which I guess does not make that much sense, if you have actions that can only be applied to one item at a time (like the move action in the example above).
• I have seen some apps, that add a button, which opens a spinner/drop-down to access the additional actions.
• Expand/collapse like here: <https://www.google.com/design/spec/components/lists-controls.html#lists-controls-types-of-list-controls> might also be an option.
• And of course there is also the option to go iOS-style on the Android app like they did in the example image.

Do anyone of you have ideas for how this should be solved? Has anyone of you had experience with this? What did you do?
This question might not be specific enough for concrete feedback, so let me know, if I can supply more info.
pretty sure popup menu will roughly get you what you are looking for in that image <http://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/PopupMenu.html>
as for performing actions in a list, I would prefer the list have one action ability whatever is most important like delete
for further actions it would be best to long press select allowing the user to start bulk actions (look at contextual action bars)

Yeah, I'm leaning towards the popup menu approach, like Play Music and Play Store. It will be different from the iOS equivalent in it's initial state, because it will require a button to click, but at least the user will notice that there are additional available actions
well in the future, this is a good A/B test
I was considering also pushing for only having one single secondary action available, and then moving any additional actions into the details view, that is reached when you press the list item
<@U053Q66UQ> I had a similar thing in one app I worked on, went with swipe on the list to reveal stuff like in the example you’ve posted
Yeah, good point about A/B testing. Hopefully when the app is released, we can also get some analytics to see which actions are most popular, so we can more easily decide :simple_smile:
